title: Quiz 8: Medicine FQE July 2013 Paper I
description: Medicine Paper I from July 2013. Clinical scenarios and essay questions converted into interactive case studies and multiple-select questions.

questions.question: Read the case of Kamau (70y) and select the correct Diagnosis and Management steps:

richContent.content:
Case Study 1

Patient: Kamau, 70-year-old male.
Symptoms: Generalized body swelling (Anasarca), Difficulty breathing (Dyspnea), Fatigue.
Signs: Sick looking, Orthopnea (uncomfortable supine), Edema, Elevated JVP.

options.text: Management: Nurse in cardiac position (propped up)

questions.explanation: The clinical picture (Orthopnea, Raised JVP, Edema) confirms Heart Failure. Treatment involves offloading fluid (Diuretics), reducing afterload (ACEIs), and positioning.

questions.question: Review the case of the 26-year-old lady and select the Diagnosis and Specific Treatment:

richContent.content:
Case Study 2

Patient: 26-year-old female.
History: Productive cough (21 days), Weight loss, Insomnia, Night sweats.
Exam: Cervical lymphadenopathy, RR 26/min, Bilateral coarse crepitations.

options.text: Rx: Intensive Phase 2RHZE (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol)

questions.explanation: Chronic cough (>2 weeks), night sweats, and weight loss are classic PTB. Treatment is standard 6-month anti-TB therapy (2RHZE/4RH).

questions.question: Mrs. Sharon presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia. Exam: Restless, disoriented, sunken eyes, sweet breath smell. BP 80/30, RBS 33mmol/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Triad of Hyperglycemia (33mmol), Dehydration/Shock (80/30, sunken eyes), and Ketosis (Sweet/fruity breath) confirms DKA.

questions.question: Arrange the management steps for Mrs. Sharon (DKA with Shock):
questions.explanation: Fluid resuscitation is the immediate priority for shock. Insulin follows. Potassium is critical but typically started after ensuring no anuria/hyperkalemia. Dextrose is late management.

questions.question: A patient presents with confusion, headache, and fever. Exam: Febrile, disoriented, neck stiffness, positive Kernig's sign. Select appropriate investigations:
questions.explanation: The clinical picture is Meningitis. LP is diagnostic. Blood culture checks for septicemia. Glucose is needed to compare with CSF glucose.
questions.hint: Investigating an infection of the brain coverings.

questions.question: A patient is unconscious following a domestic quarrel. Exam: Excessive sweating, pinpoint pupils, wet chest, Bradycardia (30bpm). What is the specific Antidote? (Name only)
questions.explanation: This is Organophosphate Poisoning (Cholinergic toxidrome). Atropine is the physiological antidote. Pralidoxime is the specific antidote.

questions.question: Select the correct components of management for Cerebral Malaria:
questions.explanation: Key steps: ICU care, specific antimalarial (Artesunate > Quinine), seizure control, and sugar control. Fluid should be conservative to avoid pulmonary edema.
questions.hint: Treat the parasite and the complications (seizures, low sugar).

questions.question: Select the causes and features of Nephritic Syndrome:
questions.explanation: Nephritic syndrome is inflammation (Hematuria, HTN, mild edema). Massive proteinuria is Nephrotic. PSGN is a classic cause.

questions.question: Select the clinical features of Iron Deficiency Anemia:
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency causes epithelial changes (nails, tongue, mouth) and craving for non-foods (Pica). Jaundice is hemolytic.

questions.question: A pneumonia patient is not improving after 3 days of Penicillin/Gentamycin. Select possible reasons for non-response:

options.text: The patient is drinking too much water

questions.explanation: Treatment failure suggests: Wrong diagnosis, Wrong drug (resistance/atypical), or Complications (pus in chest).

questions.question: Select common causes of Liver Cirrhosis:
questions.explanation: Cirrhosis results from chronic, long-term damage. Hepatitis A is acute and does not cause cirrhosis.
